p: One year later the same research group assessed the presence of 7-isopentenyloxycoumarin in common foods such as spinach (leaves), goji (berries), and quinoa (seeds), applying different mixtures of extracting solvents, namely EtOH, H 2O/EtOH 3:7, and H 2O/EtOH 7:3, under microwave irradiation coupled to UHPLC/PDA analysis [ 20]. In this case ethanol was shown to be the most efficient in terms of extractive yields. 7-Isopentenyloxycoumarin was detected only in extracts from spinach leaves and goji berries in concentration values of 2.33 µg/g and 8.37 µg/g of dry extract, respectively. Noteworthy results from this study were the confirmation of the presence of an oxyprenylated coumarin in the Amaranthaceae family after those obtained with A. retroflexus (in the case of Spinacia oleracea L.) and the first report of its determination in a species belonging to the Solanaceae family (in the case of Lycium barbarum L.).
